author: Rebecca Sullivan
title: British designer Hussein Chalayan creates coats that melt in the rain | The
text:
BRITISH designer Hussein Chalayan is known for his groundbreaking designs.
His previous collections have included two-in-one dresses and garments embedded with laser beams. And now he’s sent tongues wagging at Paris Fashion Week over his dissolvable coats.
At his Chalayan Spring Summer 2016 show, two models clad in white lab coats stopped on the runway as simulated rain began to pour above them, dissolving the coats to reveal black and white Swarovski crystal-embellished dresses underneath.
Water falls on models as they present creations by designer Hussein Chalayan as part of his Spring/Summer 2016 women's ready-to-wear collection show Picture: Charles Platiau. Source: Reuters
Once the coats dissolved, Chalayan’s Swarovski-encrusted dresses were revealed. Picture: Charles Platiau. Source: Reuters
Mr Chalayan has collaborated with Swarovski for a decade.
“I feel that if you use the crystal as an actual ingredient, as a basis for design, as opposed to only decoration, that’s when you get the most successful results,” he told Vogue .
“I try to think of it inside out, so I work with an idea where the crystal is integral to design rather than something you add on.”
Dissolvable coats (Frame content direct link: https://instagram.com/p/8VPFMYC-dK/embed .)
Picture: Charles Platiau. Source: Reuters
The Cyprus-born Brit, who is also the creative director of sports brand Puma, celebrated his 21st year in business this year and opened his first store in London’s Mayfair to coincide with the anniversary.
He was crowned ‘British Designer of the Year’ in 1999 and 2000 and was awarded a Member of the Order of the British Empire (MBE) in 2006.
Cypriot-born British fashion designer Hussein Chalayan. Picture: Miguel Medina. Source: AFP
 Would you wear clothes that melt in water?
